text:
60 year old male with a history of invasive squamous cell carcinoma of
   the oropharynx and tongue who intitially presented on [**2128-8-6**] after a
   syncopal episode at home when standing from sitting position.  He fell
   to the ground hitting his hands and knees.  There was no head trauma or
   loss of consciousness.   There was no witnessed seizure like activity.
   There was no confusion or disorientation.  He felt weak and shakey
   after he stood back up. Further history revealed poor PO intake over
   the preceding few weeks since prior discharge from the hospital on
   [**2128-7-28**].  It was during that hospitalization that his cancer was
   diagnosed.
   In the ED his initial vitals were T: 98.4, HR: 100, BP: 92/64, RR: 17,
   O2: 96% room air. Orthostatics were not checked. He had a CXR which
   showed hyperinflation but no acute cardiopulmonary abnormalities and
   multiple compression fractures of vertebrae.  He had a CT of the head
   which was negative for acute process.  Knee films were negative for
   fracture or dislocation.  He received aspirin 325 mg x1 and morphine 4
   mg IV.  He was admitted to the cardiology service given syncope and
   borderline elevated troponins (0.5).
   While on the cardiology service he was initially started on IVF for
   hydration out of concern that his syncopal episode was related to his
   poor PO intake and dehydration.  He was ruled out for myocardial
   infarction and transferred to the oncology service.  Given his poor
   oral intake he underwent PEG placement on [**2128-8-12**].  He was started on
   dexamethasone in preparation for starting chemotherapy on [**2128-8-12**].
   Also on [**2128-8-12**] the patient was noted to complain of left lower
   quadrant abdominal pain with hematuria.  He underwent CT of the abdomen
   and pelvis which did not reveal etiology of his abdominal pain but did
   show debris in the right lower lobe bronchus and right lower lobe air
   space disease most likely atelectasis with small bilateral pleural
   effusions. On [**2128-8-13**] he was started on a morphine PCA for pain control
   secondary to jaw and back pain.  Per his wife in this setting he became
   more somnolent.  Overnight on [**2128-8-14**] he was noted to develop a new 2L
   oxygen requirement.  He desaturated to 83-84% off oxygen.  CXR
   performed in this setting was concerning for bilateral pleural
   effusions and atelectasis.  He was treated with IV lasix with good
   urine output but no improvement in his oxygenation status.  On the
   morning of [**2128-8-15**] he was noted to be requiring higher levels of
   facemask oxygen up to 10L.  He was also noted to be hypotensive in the
   high 80s systolic.  He underwent emergent CTA which was negative for
   pulmonary embolism but showed right lower lobe partial collapse, debris
   in the right lobe bronchus and bilateral pleural effusions.
   On arrival to the [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] he continued to have significant oxygen
   requirement and complained of being short of breath.  Per oncology
   notes he was also complaining of left sided chest pain but he did not
   note this to ICU team.  Anesthesia and ENT were emergently consulted
   given rapidly rising oxygen requirement and lack of ability to orally
   intubate.  Decision was made to proceed with nasotracheal intubation
   which proceded without complication.  Periprocedure he was been on
   propofol with decrease in his blood pressures to the 70s systolic
   requiring levophed.
   Shock, septic

   Action:
   Response:
   Plan:
   Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**])
   Assessment:
   Action:
   Response:
   Plan:
   Pain control (acute pain, chronic pain)
